{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Georges Burou | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1910|09|06|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Tarbes]], France | death_date = {{Death date and age|1987|12|17|1910|09|06|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Mohammedia]], Morocco | death_cause = Boating accident | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = French | other_names = | alma_mater = Algiers University of Medicine | occupation = Surgeon | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{Flag|Free France}} | branch = Free French Army | serviceyears = 1943–1945 | rank = [[Second lieutenant]] | battles = [[World War II]] | awards = }} }} '''Georges Burou''' (1910–1987) was a [[France|French]] [[gynecology|gynecologist]] who managed a clinic<ref>Annals of Plastic Surgery: December 2007 - Volume 59 - Issue 6 - pp 723-729 [http://journals.lww.com/annalsplasticsurgery/Abstract/2007/12000/On_the_Origin_of_Pedicled_Skin_Inversion.24.aspx]</ref> in Casablanca, Morocco and is widely credited with innovating modern [[sex reassignment surgery]] for [[Trans woman|trans women]].<ref name="time">Staff report (January 21, 1974). [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,911027,00.html Prisoners of Sex.] ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.</ref>
Notable patients include [[Coccinelle (entertainer)|Coccinelle]], [[April Ashley]] and [[Jan Morris]].<ref>''Conundrum'', 1974, [[Jan Morris]], p. 135 - 144</ref>
Surgeons, including the late [[Stanley Biber]], have credited Burou's methods as the basis for their techniques.<ref name="wesser">Wesser, David R. A single stage operative technique for castration, vaginal construction and perineoplasty in transsexuals. ''Archives of Sexual Behavior''. Volume 7, Number 4 / July, 1978</ref>
==Early life, schooling, military service== Burou was born on September 6, 1910 in [[Tarbes]] in the [[Hautes Pyrénées]], France, while his parents were visiting the Burou family in the nearby village of Juillan.<ref>Annals of Plastic Surgery: Hage, J Joris MD, PhD; Karim, Refaat B. MD, PhD; Laub, Donald R. Sr MD, “On the Origin of Pedicled Skin Inversion Vaginoplasty: Life and Work of Dr Georges Burou of Casablanca” December 2007 - Volume 59 - Issue 6 - pp 723-729</ref> His parents worked as schoolteachers in [[Algiers]], where Burou spent his youth.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729">Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729</ref>
Burou underwent medical training at the Algiers University of Medicine.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> He specialized in [[gynecology]] and [[obstetrics]] at the Maternity of Mustapha Hospital in Algiers and became “Chef de Clinique” at Parnet Hospital in the Algiers suburb of [[Hussein Dey District|Hussein Dey]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> During his training Burou took a special interest in [[anatomy]], and later colleagues were reportedly highly impressed by his detailed knowledge of the anatomy of the [[perineum]] and [[pelvis]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
From early 1943 onward Burou first served as a second lieutenant in the [[French Expeditionary Corps (1943–44)|French Expeditionary Corps]] and eventually left North Africa as a military surgeon of the 2nd Moroccan Mountain Division to actively join battle at the French island of [[Corsica]] and the [[Italy|Italian]] river Garigliano and mountain of Cassino.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Together with [[New Zealand]] and [[India]]n troops, his division forced through the German Gustav Line at [[Cassino]] on May 13, 1944, the turning point in the liberation of Italy, and lost 1120 men in the process.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> After the liberation of [[Rome]], [[Venice]], and [[Siena]], Burou landed at [[Cassis]] for the Allied campaigns in the [[Provence]], the [[Alps]], the [[Vosges]], and the [[Alsace]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> During the subsequent liberation of [[Strasbourg|Strasburg]] in 1945, one of his best friends died in combat.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Shortly after, when in the south of [[Germany]], his service ended when he returned to Algiers to bury his father.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
==Clinique du Parc== Early reports of sex reassignment surgery had been published in Germany in the 1920s, but it was not until approximately three decades later that the practice became more generally known; early surgeries were performed mostly in Europe and [[Casablanca]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou operated his sex reassignment clinic, called “Clinique du Parc”, out of Casablanca and in 1973 reported his experience with over 3000 individual cases.<ref>Seminars in Plastic Surgery: “Aesthetic and Functional Male to Female Genital and Perineal Surgery: Feminizing Vaginoplasty”, Harold Morgan Reed, MD, May 2011 - Volume 25 - Issue 2 - pp 163-174</ref><ref>The Journal of Sexual Medicine: Goddard, Jonathan Charles MD, "Development of Feminizing Genitoplasty for Gender Dysphoria" April 19, 2009 - Volume 4 - Issue 41 - pp 981-989</ref><ref>Archive of Sexual Behaviour: Green, Richard, "The Three Kings: Harry Benjamin, John Money, Robert Stoller" June 21, 2008 - Volume 38 - pp 610-613</ref>
===Penile inversion vaginoplasty=== Between 1956 and 1958 Burou independently developed the anteriorly pedicled [[penile inversion vaginoplasty|penile skin flap inversion vaginoplasty]] in his clinic.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref>Current Opinion in Urology: “Genitoplasty in male-to-female transsexuals”, Sava Perovic, Rados Djinovic, November 2009 - Volume 16 - Issue 6 - pp 571-576</ref><ref name="Goddard, 2009, pp 981-989">Goddard, 2009, pp 981-989</ref> The technique became the “gold standard” of skin-lined vaginoplasty in [[transsexuals]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref name="Perovic, Djinovic, 2009, pp571-576">Perovic, Djinovic, 2009, pp571-576</ref> Burou performed well over 800 confirmed vaginoplasties by 1974.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref name="Perovic, Djinovic, 2009, pp571-576"/> That year, he published his technique for the first time, and presented it at the Second Interdisciplinary Symposium on Gender Dysphoria syndrome.<ref name="Goddard, 2009, pp 981-989"/> He is said to have worked at the clinic seven days a week, and more often than not, up to fifteen hours each day.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
In addition to sex-reassignment, he also performed more common obstetrics and gynecology practices from the clinic.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Outpatient appointments were held mostly in small offices in the Avenue d’Amade portion of the clinic, and the Rue Lapébie building held the operation rooms, a surgical ward, a 15-crib nursery, and delivery and patients’ rooms.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou’s wife, Jeanne (“Nanou”) Boisvert, named rooms in the clinic after different flowers, each hand-painted on small frames on the doors.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> In contrast to these warm touches, “an air of stern purpose informed the fourth floor, for these were the operating quarters.”<ref>Morris, 1974, pp 138</ref>
Contact with the outside world was initially discouraged for patients during the early days of their recovery from sex-reassignment surgery.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref name="Morris, 1974, pp 142-143">Morris, 1974, pp 142-143</ref> When patients were able to move about postoperatively, and later when going to Burou’s office to have their bandages changed, the clinic became a place where patients often had the opportunity to meet other transsexuals from various countries<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref name="Morris, 1974, pp 142-143"/> Morris recalls: “How many there were of us, I do not know, but we were of several varieties. We were Greek, French, American, British.”<ref>Morris, 1974, pp 143</ref>
==Methods==
===Patient selection and bedside manner===
Burou reported all of his vaginoplasty patients to have been prepared, to have undergone psychiatric care, and hormonal therapy.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> However, patient [[Jan Morris]] wrote that Burou did not bother too much with diagnosis or previous treatment.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref>Morris, 1974, pp 135-144</ref> Burou later confirmed that he did not ask his patients too many questions, but sought to fulfil their wishes, and that he did restrict his services to [[trans woman|male-to-female]] (MTF) transsexuals with a distinct “feminine” appearance or character.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> He refused his services to minors even if they had parental consent, because he felt “the operation is definitive and irreversible and one… could not risk making a mistake.”<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> His international patients were often admitted the afternoon they arrived at the clinic, and were prepared for surgery as soon as that evening or the next morning.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
Jan Morris, who was one of Burou’s most prominent MTF patients, recalled in her memoir ''Conundrum'' that he would do his rounds twice daily “dressed for the corniche and looking in general pretty devastating.”<ref name="Morris, 1974, pp 142">Morris, 1974, pp 142</ref> Morris recalled that he would sit at the end of her bed “and chat desultorily of this and that, type a few very slow words on [her] typewriter, read a headline from ''The Times'' in a delectable [[Maurice Chevalier]] accent, and eventually take an infinitely gentle look at his handiwork.”<ref name="Morris, 1974, pp 142"/>
Burou had little interest in finance and did not like to discuss financial matters with his patients; Morris quotes him: “You know my fee? Ah well, perhaps you will discuss it with my receptionist; bien, au revoir, until this evening!”<ref name="Morris, 1974, pp 137">Morris, 1974, pp 137</ref>
===Burou's vaginoplasty procedure===
The entire surgical procedure was done in one operation consisting of two successive parts (which remains the prevailing methodology): (1) the creation of a space between the [[rectum]] and the [[prostate]], and (2) the lining of this space with [[penis|penile]] skin after the latter had been separated from its contents.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou was acknowledged for his “results that are cosmetically excellent.”<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
According to Burou, the operation began with an incision from the [[anus|anal]] area through the [[Perineal raphe|scrotal raphe]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> After dissecting of the [[bulb of penis|bulbus urethrae]] and both [[corpus cavernosum penis|corpora cavernosa]], the rectum and the prostate were separated by cutting all the ligaments between the bulb and the rectum.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou made a point of barring, but not damaging, the posterior aspect of the prostate so that the penile skin flap after invagination would immediately overlie this aspect, which he felt optimized the possibility of postoperative [[orgasm]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The separation was extended digitally and was considered complete as soon as two fingers or a vaginal retractor could be admitted easily.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou considered this first part of the operation to be the most important, but most risky, and stressed the importance of repeated intrarectal inspection to determine that there was no lesion to the rectal wall.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
He considered the second part of the operation to be relatively easy.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The initial incision was extended along the raphe of the scrotum to the root of the penis.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The surgical field was widened by retracting the [[scrotum|scrotal skin]] on both sides and widely exposing the [[Corpus spongiosum penis|corpus spongiosum]], both corpora cavernosa, and the two [[testicle|testes]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Once the testes and their [[wikt:pedicel|pedicles]] had been dissected, the spermatic cord was cut and [[Ligature (medicine)|ligated]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Then, both corpora cavernosa were ligated and cut at a level just distally to their attachment to the inferior ramus of the [[pubis (bone)|pubic bone]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The level of transection of the spongious bulb and [[urethra]] had to correspond with the length of the future urethra.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Subsequently, all erectile bodies were pushed out and dissected from the penile skin.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> When available, the [[foreskin]] was kept and the [[Anatomical terms of location|distal]], coronal edge of the penile skin was closed; this yielded the skin tube that was inserted as neovaginal lining.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
On the lower abdominal skin, a slight skin slit was made to allow the future urethra to be passed through upon inversion of the neovaginal lining.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> A [[Foley catheter]] was inserted and the urethra was sutured onto the catheter, about 5 cm distally from its passage through the skin.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> No skin suture was used in the urethral [[Urinary meatus|meatus]], and some kind of scar contraction was always foreseen.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Two sutures were bilaterally passed through the perianal skin and the [[levator ani]] muscles and served to tightly and firmly support an [[vaginal stent|obstetric stent]], placed in the [[neovagina]] to provide support for the inverted skin flap.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> A drain was left in the [[Posterior commissure of labia majora|posterior commissure]] and, finally, excess scrotal skin was resected to obtain a good appearance of the [[Labia majora|major labia]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
Burou’s first vaginoplasty, in 1956, took him three hours to complete, however at the height of his sex-reassignment work by 1974, performing up to six vaginoplasties a month, he could complete the procedure in one hour.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The post-op patient’s arms were strapped to the bed for the first night after the procedure.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The drain was removed 48 hours after surgery, the catheter four days, and the stent eight.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The new vagina was managed by frequent or daily insertion of fingers or retractors, and the new urethra was kept open by the daily introduction of the catheter, ensuring against neomeatal stenosis.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Most patients spent two weeks in the clinic.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref>Morris, 1974, pp 141</ref>
===Cost===
In 1975 one patient addressed Burou, requesting his services, and received a prompt reply that detailed the cost of sex-reassignment surgery at U.S. $5000 “payable in cash upon arrival, if possible in travelers cheques.”<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> The price included “12 - 15 days hospitalization at the clinic, medical care and fees included, as well as the doctor’s payment.”<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> This price is considered modest for the time based upon reports that indicated the average cost of sex-reassignment surgery was on the rise.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou is said to have been willing to make “enormous” financial concessions to his fees whenever a case “merited the operation”.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
==Personal life== Burou has been described as a “courteous gentleman” and a “charismatic man” as well as “gifted with extraordinary intelligence and dexterity.”<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> He had grey-blue eyes, bronzed skin, rather intense features, and was always casually but impeccably dressed.<ref name="Morris, 1974, pp 137"/>
He was known to have a great love of the sea and had a great proclivity for water recreation throughout his life.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> A devoted sportsman, Burou loved all nautical sports, as well as golf, was a “fierce” windsurfer, and was among the first to cross the [[Strait of Gibraltar]] on [[Waterskiing|water skis]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> He wished to become a commercial marine officer before going into medicine, and thus was at first reluctant to pursue his medical training.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
Burou spoke little English but for certain gynecological and golf vocabulary.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
Burou moved to Casablanca as a result of his fiancée, Jeanne (“Nanou”) Boisvert, whose parents had a farm there.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> It was with her assistance that he began practising gynecology and obstetrics independently in [[Morocco]], from his private quarters on the third floor of a classic colonial building at 103 Boulevard de la Gare (later called Boulevard Mohammed V after [[History of Morocco|Morocco’s independence]]).<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
On the morning of Sunday, 8 November 1942, while treating French sailors in the schoolyard of École de la Fonçiere at Rue de l’Horloge (later named Rue N’Chakra Rahal) after the arrival of [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine]] troops in Casablanca, Burou was nearly killed by a 10-kg piece of shell.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> He was protected only by the branch of a tree, and thereafter kept the piece of shell in his office, reportedly as a [[memento mori]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
In 1950 Burou and his family moved to 71 Avenue d’Amade, situated across from Casablanca’s main park, now called Parc de la Ligue-Arabe.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Burou and his wife “Nanou” built the Clinique du Parc on Rue Lapébie — the backstreet that ran parallel to the prestigious avenue.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref>Morris, 1974, pp 136</ref> Burou wanted the building attached to his office and private quarters so as “not to distance himself from his patients,” and so that he could be immediately available should a patient be admitted late at night.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> Additionally, this allowed his patients the choice of entering the clinic either from the elegant Avenue d’Amade main entrance or the more inconspicuous Rue Lapébie entrance.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
==Death== Burou continued to work at the Clinique du Parc until his death in 1987.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> On Sunday 17 December his boat ran out of fuel outside of the harbour of [[Mohammedia]], and he subsequently drowned.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> His body went undiscovered for five days.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>
==Legacy== Due to the controversial nature of the procedure, Burou is said to have kept a low profile in order to continue his practice.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> His work at Clinique du Parc, which has been described by current day plastic surgeons as “pioneering”, “innovative”, and “genius”, made Burou a notable figure in the recorded history of [[plastic surgery]].<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/><ref name="Goddard, 2009, pp 981-989"/><ref name="Perovic, Djinovic, 2009, pp571-576"/> The discretion of Burou’s clinic made him relatively unknown to his medical contemporaries, despite the fact that he was well known among many trans women around the world.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/> His level of renown was such that "going to Casablanca" became a popular colloquialism for gender confirming surgery at this time.<ref name="Goddard, 2009, pp 981-989"/> Burou was a notable resource for a great many trans women throughout much of the latter half of the 20th century.<ref name="Hage, Karim, Laub, 2007, pp723-729"/>

[[Bateman transform]] |awards = [[Senior Wrangler (University of Cambridge)|Senior Wrangler]] (1903)
[[Smith's Prize]] (1905) }} '''Harry Bateman''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Erdelyi | first1 = A. | authorlink = Arthur Erdélyi| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1947.0020 | title = Harry Bateman. 1882–1946 | journal = [[Obituary Notices of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 5 | issue = 15 | pages = 590 | year = 1947 | pmid = | pmc = }} (29 May 1882 – 21 January 1946) was an English mathematician.{{Cite journal | last1 = Erdelyi | first1 = A. | doi = 10.1112/jlms/s1-21.4.300 | title = Harry Bateman | journal = Journal of the London Mathematical Society | issue = 4 | pages = 300–310 | year = 1946 | pmid = | pmc = | volume=s1-21}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Murnaghan | first1 = F. D. | authorlink = Francis Dominic Murnaghan (mathematician)| doi = 10.1090/S0002-9904-1948-08955-8 | title = Harry Bateman 1882–1946 | journal = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society | volume = 54 | pages = 88–94 | year = 1948 | pmid = | pmc = }} ==Biography== Harry Bateman first grew to love mathematics at [[Manchester Grammar School]], and in his final year, won a scholarship to [[Trinity College, Cambridge]]. Bateman studied with coach [[Robert Alfred Herman]] preparing for [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]]. He distinguished himself in 1903 as [[Wrangler (University of Cambridge)|Senior Wrangler]] (tied with P.E. Marrack) and by winning the [[Smith's Prize]] (1905).{{acad|id=BTMN900H|name=Bateman, Harry}} He published his first paper when he was still an undergradaute student on "The determination of curves satisfying given conditions".2. 1903. The determination of curves satisfying given conditions. ''Proc. Cam. Phil. Soc.'' 12, 163 He studied in Göttingen and Paris, taught at the University of Liverpool and University of Manchester before moving to the US in 1910. First he taught at [[Bryn Mawr College]] and then [[Johns Hopkins University]]. There, working with [[Frank Morley]] in geometry, he achieved the PhD, but he had already published more than sixty papers including some of his celebrated papers before getting his PhD. In 1917 he took up his permanent position at [[California Institute of Technology]], then still called ''Throop Polytechnic Institute''. [[Eric Temple Bell]] says, "Like his contemporaries and immediate predecessors among Cambridge mathematicians of the first decade of this century [1901–1910]... Bateman was thoroughly trained in both [[mathematical analysis|pure analysis]] and [[mathematical physics]], and retained an equal interest in both throughout his scientific career."[[Eric Temple Bell]] (1946) ''Quarterly of Applied Mathematics'' 4:105–111. [[Theodore von Kármán]] was called in as an advisor for a projected aeronautics laboratory at Caltech and later gave this appraisal of Bateman.[[Theodore von Kármán]] with Lee Edson (1967) ''The Wind and Beyond'', page 124, [[Little, Brown and Company]] :In 1926 Cal Tech{{sic}} had only a minor interest in [[aeronautics]]. The professorship that came nearest to aeronautics was occupied by a shy, meticulous Englishman, Dr. Harry Bateman. He was an applied mathematician from Cambridge who worked in the field of [[fluid mechanics]]. He seemed to know everything but did nothing important. I liked him. Harry Bateman married Ethel Horner in 1912 and had a son named Harry Graham, who died as a child, later the couple adopted a daughter named Joan Margaret. He died on his way to New York in 1946 of [[Coronary thrombosis]]. ==Scientific contributions== In 1907 Harry Bateman was lecturing at the [[University of Liverpool]] together with another senior wrangler, [[Ebenezer Cunningham]]. Together they came up in 1908 with the idea of a [[conformal group of spacetime]] (now usually denoted as {{math|C(1,3)}})Boris Kosyakov, ''Introduction to the Classical Theory of Particles and Fields'', Springer, 2007, p. 216. which involved an extension of the [[method of images]].{{cite book |author=Warwick, Andrew |title=Masters of theory: Cambridge and the rise of mathematical physics |publisher=The University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |year=2003 |pages= |isbn=0-226-87375-7 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} pages 416–24. For his part, in 1910 Bateman published ''[[:s:The Transformation of the Electrodynamical Equations|The Transformation of the Electrodynamical Equations]]''.{{Cite journal | last1 = Bateman | first1 = H. | authorlink = Harry Bateman| title = The Transformation of the Electrodynamical Equations | doi = 10.1112/plms/s2-8.1.223 | journal = Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society | pages = 223–264 | year = 1910 | pmid = | pmc = | volume=s2-8}} He showed that the [[Jacobian matrix and determinant|Jacobian]] [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] of a [[spacetime]] [[diffeomorphism]] which preserves the [[Maxwell equations]] is proportional to an [[orthogonal matrix]], hence [[conformal transformation|conformal]]. The transformation [[Lie group|group]] of such transformations has ''15 parameters'' and extends both the [[Poincaré group]] and the [[Lorentz group]]. Bateman called the elements of this group [[spherical wave transformation]]s.{{Cite journal | last1 = Bateman | first1 = H. | authorlink = Harry Bateman| title = The Conformal Transformations of a Space of Four Dimensions and Their Applications to Geometrical Optics | doi = 10.1112/plms/s2-7.1.70 | journal = Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society | pages = 70–89 | year = 1909 | pmid = | pmc = | volume=s2-7}} In evaluating this paper, one of his students, [[Clifford Truesdell]], wrote :The importance of Bateman's paper lies not in its specific details but in its general approach. Bateman, perhaps influenced by Hilbert's point of view in mathematical physics as a whole, was the first to see that the basic ideas of electromagnetism were equivalent to statements regarding integrals of [[differential form]]s, statements for which Grassmann's calculus of extension on differentiable manifolds, Poincaré's theories of Stokesian transformations and integral invariants, and Lie's theory of continuous groups could be fruitfully applied.{{cite book |author=Truesdell, C. |title=An idiot's fugitive essays on science: methods, criticism, training, circumstances |publisher=Springer-Verlag |location=Berlin |year=1984 |pages= |isbn=0-387-90703-3 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} Genius and the establishment at a polite standstill in the modern university: Bateman", pages 403 to 438 Bateman was the first to apply [[Laplace transform]] to integral equation in 1906. He submitted a detailed report on integral equation in 1911 in the British association for the advancement of science.Bateman, H. (1911). Report on the history and present state of the theory of integral equations. The Assoc.. https://archive.org/stream/reportofbritisha11scie/reportofbritisha11scie_djvu.txt [[Horace Lamb]] in his 1910 paper{{cite journal | last1 = Lamb | first1 = H | year = 1910 | title = On the diffraction of a solitary wave | url = | journal = Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society | volume = 2 | issue = 1| pages = 422–437 }} solved an integral equation :2\int_0^\infty f(y-\zeta^2)\,d\zeta = F(y) as a double integral, but in his footnote he says, "Mr. H. Bateman, to whom I submitted the question, has obtained a simpler solution in the form" :f(y) = \frac 1 \pi \int_{-y}^\infty \frac{F'(-z)}{\sqrt{z+x}}dz. In 1914 Bateman published ''The Mathematical Analysis of Electrical and Optical Wave-motion''. As Murnaghan says, this book "is unique and characteristic of the man. Into less than 160 small pages is crowded a wealth of information which would take an expert years to digest." The following year he published a [[textbook]] ''Differential Equations'', and sometime later ''Partial differential equations of mathematical physics''. Bateman is also author of ''Hydrodynamics'' and ''Numerical integration of differential equations''. Bateman studied the [[Burgers' equation]]{{cite journal | last1 = Bateman | first1 = H | year = 1915 | title = Some recent researches on the motion of fluids | url = ftp://ftp.library.noaa.gov/docs.lib/htdocs/rescue/mwr/043/mwr-043-04-0163.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Monthly Weather Review | volume = 43 | issue = 4| pages = 163–170 | doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1915)43<163:srrotm>2.0.co;2}} long before [[Jan Burgers]] started to study. Harry Bateman wrote two significant articles on the history of applied mathematics: * "The influence of tidal theory upon the development of mathematics"{{Cite journal | last1 = Bateman | first1 = H. | authorlink = Harry Bateman| title = The Influence of Tidal Theory upon the Development of Mathematics | journal = National Mathematics Magazine | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 14–26 | doi = 10.2307/3029913 | year = 1943 | pmid = | pmc = }} * "Hamilton's work in dynamics and its influence on modern thought"H. Bateman (1944) "Hamilton's work in dynamics and its influence on modern thought", [[Scripta Mathematica]] 10:51–63 In his ''Mathematical Analysis of Electrical and Optical Wave-motion'' (p. 131) he describes the charged-corpuscle trajectory as follows: :a corpuscle has a kind of tube or thread attached to it. When the motion of the corpuscle changes a wave or kink runs along the thread; the energy radiated from the corpuscle spreads out in all directions but is concentrated round the thread so that the thread acts as a guiding wire. This figure of speech is not to be confused with a [[String (physics)|string in physics]], for the universes in [[string theory]] have dimensions inflated beyond four, something not found in Bateman's work. Bateman went on to study the [[luminiferous aether]] with an article "The structure of the Aether".H. Bateman (1915) [http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1915-21-06/S0002-9904-1915-02631-5/S0002-9904-1915-02631-5.pdf The Structure of the Aether], [[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]] 21(6):299–309 His starting point is the [[bivector (complex)|bivector]] form of an [[electromagnetic field]] '''E''' + i'''B'''. He recalled [[Alfred-Marie Liénard]]'s electromagnetic fields, and then distinguished another type he calls "aethereal fields": :When a large number of "aethereal fields" are superposed their singular curves indicate the structure of an "aether" which is capable of supporting a certain type of electromagnetic field. Bateman received many honours for his contributions, including election to the [[Royal Society]] of London in 1928, election to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] in 1930. He was elected as vice-president of the [[American Mathematical Society]] in 1935 and was the Society's Gibbs Lecturer for 1943.{{cite journal|author=Bateman, H.|title=The control of an elastic fluid|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1945|volume=51|issue=|pages=601–646|mr=0014548|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1945-08413-4}} He was on his way to New York to receive an award from the Institute of Aeronautical Science when he died of [[coronary]] [[thrombosis]]. The ''Harry Bateman Research Instructorships'' at the California Institute of Technology are named in his honour.{{cite web |url=http://www.math.caltech.edu/general/08-09postdoc.html |title=Instructorships in Mathematics 2008–09 |work= |accessdate=30 January 2012}} After his death, his notes on higher transcendental functions were edited by A. Erdélyi, W. Magnus, F. Oberhettinger, and F. G. Tricomi, and published in 1954.{{cite book|author=A. Erdélyi, W. Magnus, F. Oberhettinger, F. G. Tricomi|title=Higher Transcendental Functions|publisher=McGraw-Hill|date=1954}} ==Publications== In a review of Bateman's book ''Partial Differential Equations of Mathematical Physics'', [[Richard Courant]] says that "there is no other work which presents the analytical tools and the results achieved by means of them equally completely and with as many original contributions" and also "advanced students and research workers alike will read it with great benefit". {{Div col|colwidth=32em}} * 1908: [[s:en:The Conformal Transformations of a Space of Four Dimensions and their Applications to Geometrical Optics|The Conformal Transformations of a Space of Four Dimensions and their Applications to Geometrical Optics]], ''Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society'' 7: 70–89. * 1910: [https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/94115#page/506/mode/1up History and Present State of the Theory of Integral Equations], ''Report of the [[British Association]]''. * 1914: (dissertation) [http://quod.lib.umich.edu/u/umhistmath/ABQ9961.0001.001/1?rgn=works;view=pdf;rgn1=author;q1=Bateman The Quartic Curve and its Inscribed Configurations], [[American Journal of Mathematics]] 36(4), link from University of Michigan Historical Math Collection. * 1915: [http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/3563964 The Mathematical Analysis of Electrical and Optical Wave-motion on the Basis of Maxwell's Equations], [[Cambridge University Press]], link from [[Trove]]. * 1918: ''Differential equations'', Longmans, Green, London, Reprint Chelsea 1966. * 1932: ''Partial Differential Equations of Mathematical Physics'', Cambridge University Press 1932,{{cite journal|author=Walsh, Joseph L.|authorlink=Joseph L. Walsh|title=Bateman on Mathematical Physics|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1933|volume=39|issue=3|pages=178–180|url=http://projecteuclid.org/euclid.bams/1183496570|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1933-05561-1}} Dover 1944, 1959. * 1933: (with Albert A. Bennett, William E. Milne) ''Numerical Integration of Differential Equations'', ''Bulletin of the National Research Council'', Dover 1956. * 1932: (with [[Hugh Latimer Dryden|Hugh Dryden]], [[Francis Dominic Murnaghan (mathematician)|Francis Murnaghan]]) [https://books.google.ca/books?id=rSixAAAAIAAJ Report of the Committee on Hydrodynamics], ''Bulletin of the National Research Council'', Washington D.C., link from [[Google Books]]. * 1945: "The Control of an Elastic Fluid", [[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]] 51(9):601–46, or ''Selected Papers on Mathematical Trends in Control Theory'' ([[Richard Bellman]] & Robert Kalaba editors). * [[Bateman Manuscript Project]]: ''Higher Transcendental Functions'', 3 vols., McGraw Hill 1953 to 1955, Krieger 1981. * [[Bateman Manuscript Project]]: ''Tables of Integral Transforms'', 2 vols., McGraw Hill 1954. {{colend}} ==See also== *[[Bateman Manuscript Project]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikisourceauthor}} * [http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/bateman-harry.pdf Academy of Sciences Biographical Memoir] * {{MathGenealogy|id=8181}} * {{MacTutor Biography|id=Bateman}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bateman, Harry}} [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Bryn Mawr College faculty]] [[Category:California Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:English mathematicians]] [[Category:Fluid dynamicists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University faculty]] [[Category:People educated at Manchester Grammar School]] [[Category:People from Manchester]] [[Category:Senior Wranglers]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]]

{{vgrelease|NA|July 2, 2007}} |genre = [[Strategy video game|Strategy]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Game Boy Advance]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] }} '''''Horsez''''' is a videogame released by [[Ubisoft]] on October 26, 2006 for the [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Personal computer|PC]] and [[Game Boy Advance]]. This PC game is the sequel to ''[[Champion Dreams: First to Ride]]'' and is also part of the second series of [[Petz]]. In ''Horsez'', you play as Flora (this is the default name), a new member of the Sycamore Academy. Players can select a horse from one of 5 breeds and a range of colours. The player trains their horse in different disciplines, enters shows, cares for their horse, and after a few weeks gains a foal to raise. ''Horsez'' is also known as ''[[Pippa Funnell]] 3: The Golden Stirrup Challenge.'' ==Gameplay== As the player, you have to arrange your timetable so that you can pass each week. To pass, you must obtain a certain score out of 10 for each of the disciplines, and must train in that discipline at least twice a week. The disciplines are Horse Care, Cross Country, Dressage, Showjumping, and later Foal Care and Learning. You must also have a high social rating, which is obtained by spending time in the Student Centre talking to other academy riders, performing well in disciplines, taking and displaying photographs in the Student Centre, and purchasing items from the shops. Between training and caring for your horse, foal, and talking to the other riders, you may go shopping, change your attire in your bedroom, study in the library and go for a walk with your horse. In each country, there are a number of secrets to find. These are small figurines, and there are 10 in total. Throughout the game, the player is sometimes given control of the protagonist or the horse, and can move around freely. There are numerous cutscenes, events where your character has to find something (some of these can be very difficult) and riddles. Preceding many events is a journal entry with a voiceover. These events, combined with the contrasting disciplines, ensure the gameplay is variable. ==Starting== First, the player must choose a name for the character they will be playing and a mount. The player can choose from 5 breeds: [[Arabian]] Thoroughbred, English [[Thoroughbred]], [[Connemara pony|Connemara]], [[Appaloosa]] and [[Saddlebred]]. Each breed has a range of colours including a number of shades of brown, bay and grey. After the horse is selected and named (the horse's name is ignored for the rest of the game), play begins with a journal entry and a cutscene. The player is then given control of the horse. ==Characters== The main character is Flora and her horse. Other characters include the staff at the riding academy, fellow riders, and later the player's rival, Daniela. Daniela's director is Esteban, who had a previous relationship with Jade. '''Friends:'''
Miguel: Male, short brown hair, glasses. Shy, loves poetry. Has a crush on the protagonist.
Samuel: Male, dark skin, black hair. Loves loud rock music.
Caroll: Female, red hair. Fairly quiet, can be a bit slow.
Aurelie: Female, brown hair. Plays the violin. Likes fashion. In the Student Centre, the player can talk to these friends and learn their stories. ==Disciplines== '''Horse Care:''' Taking care of a horse. Horse Care includes hosing, grooming, picking his hooves and mucking his stall. It is best to do this at least 3 times a week. '''Cross Country:''' You canter your horse around the course, pressing the spacebar key to jump when you are in the right spot (there is a green circle that you must be in when you jump, otherwise your horse will balk or throw you). '''Dressage:''' You press the left and right arrow keys in time to make your horse perform the correct gait. Other keys are also used to control your horse and halt and salute. You need to go to the library and read the books on all the gaits each week to ensure you know them all, otherwise your horse won't do them. '''Showjumping:''' A fairly difficult discipline to master. You canter inside the ring following the arrows and jumping at the jumps. '''Foal Care:''' Once you have your foal, you have to take care of it. During Foal Care, your foal will perform 3 actions. You need to guess what the foal wants based on what it does. Each week, you should go to the library and read up on foal care, and take notes so you can look at them and decide which action you think your foal is doing, and act accordingly. '''Learning:''' Once you have your foal, you need to raise it. Learning involves you teach your foal different gaits. ==Horsez 2== A sequel was created for Horsez. With somewhat similar plots: the main character is a young woman named Emma. She was sent to France to train to become a veterinarian. However, with the taxi broken down, she has no choice but to take refuge in a small, quiet town. There, she meets Oliver, a nephew of his aunt's stud farm, who is missing its real owner, Marie. After finding out Emma is a vet, he offers to give her shelter if she helps them with a mare in foal. Emma agrees, after meeting Flora, Micheal (formerly called Miguel in Horsez), and Carol, the character is given some objectives. The character delivers a healthy foal, and then is given the choice of the player to stay with the stud farm or leave as a vet. Either way, the game still continues. Most of the main parts are: The character is given a challenge to spy on the Mayor, who wants to take over the stud farm for a housing development. The character saves Oliver in three different ways. The character is given secondary objectives to complete. The character competes in competitions for extra money and horse breeds. In the end, the characters win back the stud farm, though end results are dependent on the player's choices throughout the game. In one part, find out that Marie is still alive and well. In this ending she leaves the stud farm to Flora, and promises to visit soon, having settled in New Zealand. Other possible endings include Emma getting Oliver (and herself) tickets to the US so she can show him her country, and Emma and Oliver sharing a kiss on the beach. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110219220015/http://petz.uk.ubi.com/ Ubisoft's Official Petz Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110210105813/http://petz.us.ubi.com/horsez/ Ubisoft's US Horsez Website] *[http://www.pippafunnellgame.com Official Pippa Funnell games Website] [[Category:2006 video games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:Ubisoft games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Virtual pet video games]] [[Category:Windows games]]

{{Other people|James Adams}} '''James Blake Adams''' (c. 1749 – after 1794) was an [[England|English]] composer, organist, and cellist. He is known for many small instrumental and vocal [[Musical composition|composition]]s between 1770 and 1820. He is best known for the song, ''[[The Nightingale (Adams)|The Nightingale]]'', which remains popular.
He was organist for Brompton Chapel in 1784 and is known to have performed cello in various concerts from then on, most notably the [[Handel]] commemoration concerts of 1784 and the annual concerts for the relief of the clergy at [[St. Paul's Cathedral]].
==His compositions== Adams changed his musical style from time to time. His early songs on the [[harpsichord]] had the manner of [[Thomas Arne]], his canzonets accompanied by chamber [[orchestra]] referred slightly to [[J. C. Bach]], and his violin and cello [[sonata]]s were closed to the works of [[Haydn]].
==Books== * ''A Familiar Introduction to the First Principles of Music'', 1815.
==References== * {{GroveOnline|title=James B. Adams|author=Robin Langley|access-date=January 14, 2014}} * Adams: Beach Bluff Waltzes. Edited by White, Smith & Company, 1875. * http://browse.musicspace.mspace.fm/record/472163/Adams_James_B_lake_1749-1794
{{authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person |honorific_prefix = Captain |name = James Teare |honorific_suffix = |image = Capt. James Teare of the RMS Ellan Vannin..JPG |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1872|8|6|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Peel, Isle of Man]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1909|12|3|1872|8|6|df=y}} |death_cause = Drowned as a result of the foundering of the RMS ''Ellan Vannin''; body washed ashore on Ainsdale Beach, January 1910 |death_place = [[Liverpool Bay]] |nationality = British |occupation = Ship [[Captain (naval)|captain]] |employer = [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] |known_for = [[Sea captain|Captain]] of [[Royal Mail Ship|RMS]] [[SS Ellan Vannin (1883)|''Ellan Vannin]]. |spouse = Niobe Cowley |parents = Thomas Teare, Margaret Teare |children = James (Jim) Teare, Douglas Cowley Teare, Edith May Teare, Alfred Bertram Teare |relatives = |footnotes = }}
'''James Teare''' (6 August 1872 – 3 December 1909) was a [[Manx people|Manx]] [[merchant navy]] officer who served as a [[Ship transport#Professional mariners|seaman]] and later as an officer on numerous [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] vessels. Capt. Teare is best known as the [[Master mariner|Master]] of the [[SS Ellan Vannin (1883)|RMS ''Ellan Vannin'']] on her ill-fated voyage from [[Ramsey, Isle of Man]] to [[Liverpool]] on 3 December 1909.<ref name="ReferenceB">''The Isle of Man Examiner.'' Saturday, December 11, 1909</ref>
==Life and career== James Teare was born in [[Peel, Isle of Man]] on 6 August 1872 and raised at St German's Place. He made his career at sea, joining the [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] in 1891 as a [[Ship transport#Professional mariners|seaman]], rising through the ranks and serving on the [[SS Mona's Isle (1882)|''Mona's Isle'']] as well as various other company ships. [[File:Mona's Isle crew..jpg|thumb|left|The crew of [[SS Mona's Isle (1882)|''Mona's Isle'']] ''(circa 1900).'' [[Second mate|Second Officer]] James Teare can be seen seated at the far left of the photograph.]]
As his career progressed he served as [[Chief mate|First Officer]] under Capt. Hill on the [[SS Snaefell (1876)|''Snaefell'']]<ref>''Isle of Man Times''. Saturday July 23rd, 1904 p.7)</ref> and following Capt. Hill's resignation from the company he gained his first command on the ''Ellan Vannin'' which he assumed in July 1904.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> This was followed in turn by him taking command of the [[SS Fenella (1881)|''Fenella'']]<ref>''The Ramsey Courier'' Friday July 7th, 1905 (p.5).</ref> in 1905 and the [[SS Douglas (1889)|''Douglas'']] in May 1906.<ref>''The Mona's Herald.'' Wednesday May 30th, 1906 (p.6).</ref> He then left the [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] and pursued a career with an international shipping line before returning to the [[Isle of Man]] and re-joining the Steam Packet Company.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
The summer of 1909 saw Capt. Teare in command of the [[SS King Orry (1871)|''King Orry.'']]<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Following the summer season he went on shore leave and as the year closed he resumed command of the ''Ellan Vannin'' for a month's winter service, which by December 1909 was the smallest and oldest vessel in the Steam Packet Fleet.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Known for being a cautious and diligent captain as well as a lifelong [[Teetotalism|teetotaler]], James Teare was married with four children and lived at No 9 York Road, [[Douglas, Isle of Man]].<ref name="ReferenceB"/> [[File:Ellan Vannin departing Douglas.jpg|thumb|left|RMS ''Ellan Vannin'' pictured departing Douglas.]]
==''Ellan Vannin'' disaster== {{main|SS Ellan Vannin (1883)}} On 3 December 1909, ''Ellan Vannin'' left her home port of [[Ramsey, Isle of Man|Ramsey]] at [[24-hour clock#Midnight 00:00 and 24:00|01:13hrs]], under the command of [[Sea captain|Captain]] Teare.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> ''Ellan Vannin'' was carrying 15 passengers and 21 crew as well as mail and 60 tonnes of cargo which included approximately 60 sheep. The weather on departure was moderate and although the [[barometric pressure]] was falling [[Sea captain|Captain]] Teare did not expect a significant deterioration in the weather. The wind direction on departure was from the northwest meaning the ''Ellan Vannin'' would have a following sea during her passage, something which would have caused her [[Sea captain|Master]] no particular concern.<ref name="ReferenceA">''The Isle of Man Examiner.'' December 4th, 1909, (p.9)</ref> However, the weather rapidly worsened and by [[24-hour clock#Midnight 00:00 and 24:00|06:35hrs]], when the ship arrived at the [[River Mersey|Mersey]] Bar [[Lightvessel|Lightship]], the wind had risen to a [[Beaufort scale|Hurricane Force 12]], and [[wind wave|wave]]s were reported to be exceeding {{convert|24|ft|m|0}} in height.<ref>Ships of the Isle of Man Steam Packet Company (Fred Henry, 1973) p.10</ref>
A strong consensus at the time<ref name="ReferenceA"/> was that with a following sea the ''Ellan Vannin'' had made good progress to the Bar Lightship.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Upon reaching the Bar her course would have been changed from approximately 130 degrees to 080 degrees as she entered the approach channel to the river. This would have caused her to take the sea on her port beam with the result that she got sufficiently off her course to strike a sandbank<ref name="ReferenceA"/> thereby causing her to [[Shipwrecking|founder]], (a [[Glossary of nautical terms|nautical term]] for filling with water and sinking), between the Bar [[Lightvessel|lightship]] and the [[Buoy|Q1 buoy]] sinking in the [[River Mersey|Mersey]] approach channel (at {{Coord|53|32|0|N|3|17|0|W|display=inline,title}}).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?5054| title=SS Ellan Vannin [+1909]| publisher=Wreck site| accessdate=6 October 2013| registration=yes}}</ref> It is believed she was [[Broach (sailing)|broached]] by a large wave, which overwhelmed the ship. She was swept by heavy seas and filled, sinking by the stern with the loss of all passengers and crew. [[File:Captain Teare's House.jpg|thumb|left|The home of Captain James Teare, York Road, [[Douglas, Isle of Man]].]][[File:Captain Teare's Grave.jpeg|thumb|right|The grave of Captain James Teare, Douglas Borough Cemetery, Douglas, Isle of Man.]] News of the disaster reached [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]] on the Friday evening, and the directors sat in almost continuous session until Monday. Communication was by [[telegraphy|telegram]] and information was difficult to ascertain. At approximately [[24-hour clock#Midnight 00:00 and 24:00|19:00hrs]]<ref name="ReferenceA"/> a telegram was received which reported that the crew of the [[Formby]] [[Lightvessel|Lightship]] had seen [[lifebuoy]]s, bags of turnips, several dead sheep and a piano floating near the [[Lightvessel|lightship]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> It was also reported that the crew of the lightship had picked up a mail bag which was destined for the [[Birkenhead]] [[Post Office]] and which was found to contain letters despatched from [[Ramsey, Isle of Man|Ramsey]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The following morning the company offices in [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]] received a [[telegram]] from [[Liverpool]] stating that one of the ''Ellan Vannin's'' [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboats]] had been washed ashore at [[New Brighton, Merseyside|New Brighton]] with its cover on and its working gear inside.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Also washed ashore were parts of the ship's [[Bridge (nautical)|bridge]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
It was five days after the ship went down that the first bodies were recovered. On Monday 17 January 1910 Captain Teare's body was found washed ashore on [[Ainsdale]] beach in [[Southport]]<ref name="ReferenceD"/> with an inquest into his death being held on Wednesday 19 January.<ref name="ReferenceD">''Ramsey Courier.'' Friday January 21, 1910 (p.4)</ref> Also on 17 January the body of [[Chief mate|First Officer]] John Craine was found.<ref name="ReferenceD"/> It too had been washed ashore at Southport.<ref name="ReferenceD"/> Both bodies were subsequently returned to the [[Isle of Man]] for burial.
===Aftermath=== [[File:GetImage256CP6ZX.png|thumb|right|Headline in the ''Ramsey Courier,'' Saturday 10 December 1909.]]The [[Board of Trade]] inquiry found that [[Sea captain|Captain]] Teare was not to blame for the disaster and the cause was [[extreme weather]]. The official inquiry referred to waves {{convert|24|ft|0}} high and declared the ship to have been in good condition and fully [[seaworthy]]. After the [[Shipwreck (accident)|foundering]], her masts broke the surface. Divers inspecting the ship found damage to the bows and that the lifeboat davits had been swung out ready for lowering. Soon after the disaster the [[Mersey Docks and Harbour Board]] destroyed the [[Shipwreck|wreck]] using explosives, as it was causing a hazard to shipping in the channel.
Although the [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] has a tradition of reusing ship names, they have never reused the name {{lang|gv|Ellan Vannin}}.
A song written by Hughie Jones of [[The Spinners (UK band)|The Spinners]] commemorates the disaster.

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Jessica McClure | image = | birth_name = Jessica McClure | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|3|26}} | birth_place = [[Midland, Texas]], U.S. | known_for = falling into a well at 18 months | other_names = Jessica McClure Morales | spouse = {{marriage|Daniel Morales|2006}} | children = 2 }} '''Jessica McClure Morales''' (born March 26, 1986) became famous on October 14, 1987, at the age of 18 months after she fell into a [[water well|well]] in her aunt's backyard in [[Midland, Texas]]. Between that day and October 16, rescuers worked for 56 hours to free her from the {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on|spell=in}} [[casing (borehole)|well casing]] {{convert|22|ft|m}} below the ground.{{cite web|url=http://abc13.com/30-years-ago-rescue-of-baby-jessica-from-the-well/1555516/|title=30 years ago: Rescue of 'Baby Jessica' from the well|date=October 14, 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/18-month-old-girl-saved-1987-article-1.2386153|title=Jessica McClure, an 18-month-old girl, is saved after 58 long hours trapped in a well in 1987 - NY Daily News|publisher=}} The story gained worldwide attention (leading to some criticism as a [[media circus]]), and later became the subject of a 1989 [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television movie ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]''. == Rescue == McClure's rescue proved to be a much more difficult ordeal than was first anticipated. Within hours of beginning the emergency procedure, the Midland Fire and Police Departments devised a plan that involved drilling another shaft parallel to the well and then drilling a tunnel at a right angle across to it. Enlisting the help of a variety of local (often out-of-work) oil-drillers, the Midland officials had hoped to free McClure in minutes. However, the first workers to arrive on the scene found their tools barely adequate to penetrate the hard rock around the well. It took about six hours to drill the shaft and longer to drill the tunnel, because the [[jackhammer]]s used were designed for drilling downward, rather than sideways. A mining engineer eventually arrived to help supervise and coordinate the rescue effort. TV viewers watched as paramedics and rescuers, drilling experts and contractors worked tirelessly to save the baby's life. Meanwhile, they were reassured when they heard Jessica singing “[[Winnie the Pooh (song)|Winnie the Pooh]]” from deep in the well. As long as she was still singing, they knew she was still alive.{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Darla|title=Baby Jessica 30 Years Later: 'My Life Is a Miracle'|url=http://people.com/human-interest/baby-jessica-30-years-later-my-life-is-a-miracle/|accessdate=15 October 2017|website=People.com|date=31 May 2017|quote=Television viewers watched as hundreds of paramedics, rescuers, drilling experts and contractors feverishly worked to save the baby's life. Meanwhile, they were reassured when they heard Jessica singing “[[Winnie the Pooh (song)|Winnie the Pooh]]” from deep in the well. As long as she was singing, she was still alive.}} Forty-five hours after McClure fell into the well, the shaft and tunnel were finally completed. The relatively new technology of [[Water jet cutter|waterjet cutting]], used to cut through the hard rock surrounding the well, was a vital part of the rescue.{{cite book|title=Business Week|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p-0dAQAAMAAJ|year=1989|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.}}{{cite book|author=National Science Foundation (U.S.)|title=Annual report for fiscal year ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7EEc-gZcTJkC|year=1987|publisher=The Foundation}} Ron Short, a muscular roofing contractor who was born without collar bones because of [[cleidocranial dysostosis]] and so could collapse his shoulders to work in cramped corners, arrived at the site and offered to go down the shaft. They considered his offer, but did not use it.{{cite news |first= J. Michael |last= Kennedy |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-10-17/news/mn-3702_1_jessica-mcclure |title=Jessica Makes It to Safety—After 58 1/2 Hours |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 17, 1987 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}{{cite journal|first=Ronald W. |last=Scott |url=http://www.jospt.org/members/getfile.asp?id=3740 |format=PDF |title=Cleidocranial Dysplasia: An Enigma Among Anomalies |journal=The Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy |date=November 1988 |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=184–8 |issn=0190-6011 |accessdate=November 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404192505/http://www.jospt.org/members/getfile.asp?id=3740 |archivedate=April 4, 2012 |df= }} One report said that he helped to clear tunneling debris away.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcuniversalarchives.com/nbcuni/clip/5112434055_s02.do|title=Home - News, Entertainment, World Events Video - NBCUniversal Archives|website=NBCUniversal Archives|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} Midland Fire Department paramedic Robert O'Donnell was ultimately able to inch his way into the tunnel and wrestle McClure free from the confines of the well, handing her to fellow paramedic Steve Forbes, who carried her up to safety. == Media coverage == [[CNN]] was on the scene with around-the-clock coverage of the rescue effort. This massive media saturation of the ordeal prompted then-President [[Ronald Reagan]] to state that "everybody in America became godmothers and godfathers of Jessica while this was going on." From the beginning and throughout the incident, the switchboard of local media outlet [[KMID-TV]] was flooded with telephone calls from news organizations and private individuals around the world, seeking the latest information on rescue efforts. In some cases, they shared their own insight into this and similar incidents. In 1988, McClure and her parents appeared on ''[[Live with Regis and Kathie Lee]]'' to talk about the incident. The photograph of McClure being rescued fetched the [[1988 Pulitzer Prize|1988]] [[Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography|Pulitzer Prize for Spot News Photography]] to Scott Shaw of the ''[[Odessa American]]''.{{cite web |author= Staff |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/awards/1988 |title= 1988 Winners and Finalists |work= The Pulitzer Prizes |publisher= Columbia University |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} ABC made a television movie of the story in 1989, ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]'', starring [[Patty Duke]] and [[Beau Bridges]]. It featured many participants in the actual rescue and its coverage as extras. On May 30, 2007, ''[[USA Today]]'' ranked McClure number 22 on its list of "25 lives of indelible impact."{{cite web|last=Koch |first=Wendy |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/top25-people.htm |title=Lives of Indelible Impact |work= [[USA Today]] |date=May 29, 2007 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} == Aftermath == [[File:President George H.W. Bush holds Jessica McClure in the Roosevelt Room at the White House (1989-07-19).jpg|thumb|President [[George H. W. Bush]] meeting McClure at the White House in 1989]] Following McClure's rescue on October 16, 1987, surgeons had to amputate a toe due to [[gangrene]] from loss of circulation while she was in the well. She also has a scar on her forehead where her head rubbed against the well casing. She had 15 surgeries over the years and has no first-hand memory of the event.{{cite web |url= http://www9.comcast.net/articles/news-national/20110325/US.Baby.Jessica/ |last= Blaney |first= Betsy |title= Baby Jessica turns 25, gains access to trust fund |work= Xfinity News |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= March 25, 2011 |accessdate= March 25, 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110326215656/http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-national/20110325/US.Baby.Jessica/ |archivedate= March 26, 2011}} Her parents divorced a few years after the rescue. Paramedic Robert O'Donnell, battling [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] as a result of the arduous rescue effort and struggling to cope with the abrupt decline of the fame and recognition that had been lavished on him following his heroic act, committed suicide in 1995.{{cite news |last1=Belkin|first1=Lisa |title=Death on the CNN Curve |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/23/magazine/death-on-the-cnn-curve.html |accessdate=July 18, 2017 |work=The New York Times |date=July 23, 1995}} McClure graduated from [[Greenwood Independent School District|Greenwood High School]], in a small community near Midland, in May 2004. On January 28, 2006, nineteen-year-old McClure married Daniel Morales at [[Church of Christ]] in [[Notrees, Texas]], about 40 miles from Midland. They met at a day care center where she worked with his sister.{{cite news |last= Celizic |first= Mike |url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19165433/ |title= Baby Jessica 20 Years Later |publisher= [[MSNBC]] |date= November 6, 2007 |accessdate= November 24, 2010}} They have two children, a boy born 2007 and a girl born 2009.{{cite news|url=https://people.com/human-interest/baby-jessica-on-the-30-year-anniversary-of-her-rescue-from-a-well-her-life-as-a-wife-and-mom/|title=Baby Jessica On the 30 Year Anniversary of Her Rescue from a Well: Her Life as a Wife and Mom|first=Steve|last=Helling|date=October 16, 2017|publisher=[[People magazine]]}} When McClure turned 25 on March 26, 2011, she received a [[escrow|trust fund]] of donations worth up to $800,000. Her father said she had discussed setting up a trust fund for the college education of her children. It had earlier helped in the purchase of her present home, which is less than {{convert|2|mi|km|spell=in}} from the site of the incident. == In popular culture == * Footage of McClure's rescue appeared in [[Michael Jackson]]'s music video for the song "[[Man in the Mirror]]".{{YouTube|PivWY9wn5ps|Michael Jackson - Man In The Mirror (Official Video); 3:45}} * [[Lucie Brock-Broido]]'s long narrative poem "Jessica from the Well" (1988) tells the story from McClure's point of view, describing her as having a basic understanding of the physical and mythic elements of her situation. It has been reprinted numerous times.{{cite book |first= Lucie |last= Brock-Broido |chapter= Jessica, from the Well |title= A Hunger |location= New York |publisher=Knopf |year= 1988 |isbn= 978-0-394-56337-4 }} * A 1990 Indian movie, ''[[Malootty]]'', was based on the incident.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Radio Bart]]" (1992) revolved around a similar incident.http://www.popmatters.com/column/119350- the-simpsons-radio-bart-9-january-1992-part-2/{{cite web|url=http://www.gabbinggeek.com/2016/03/30/simpsons-did-it-radio-bart/|title=Simpsons Did It!: "Radio Bart"|date=March 30, 2016|website=Gabbinggeek.com|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} * In the 1995 film ''[[12 Monkeys]]'', a heavily fictionalized version of the Jessica McClure story plays out in TV and radio newscasts throughout the film. The entire nation is transfixed as a nine-year-old boy named "Ricky Newman" is believed to have fallen down a well in Fresno, California. Rescuers similarly dig a second well parallel to the one they think he is in, but James Cole (Bruce Willis) tells Kathryn Railly (Madeleine Stowe) that the boy is, in fact, hiding in a barn. He is later proven right. He knows this because he is a time traveler and remembers the events from when he was a child. * In 2010, [[blues]] musician [[Charlie Musselwhite]] released an album titled ''The Well''. In the title song he credits McClure's ordeal for inspiring him to quit drinking.{{cite news |url= http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/turn_it_up/2010/09/how-baby-jessica-saved-blues-great-charlie-musselwhite.html |title= How 'Baby Jessica' Saved Blues Great Charlie Musselwhite |first= Greg |last= Kot |work= [[Chicago Tribune]] |date= September 28, 2010 |accessdate= June 4, 2013}} * A 2012 episode of ''[[American Dad!]]'' titled "[[National Treasure 4: Baby Franny: She's Doing Well: The Hole Story]]" featured a storyline which was essentially a parody of McClure's story, including a story revolving around the misfortunes of her rescuer.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *In a ''[[Modern Family]]'' episode "Heavy is the Head" (2017) Cam reveals he fell into a well the same day as McClure, but she got all the press.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/cams-bitter-rivalry-with-baby-jessica-on-modern-family-070139822.html|title=Cam's Bitter Rivalry With Baby Jessica on 'Modern Family'|website=Yahho.com|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} == See also == * [[Floyd Collins]], an early case of "man trapped in cave" that received similar coverage in 1925 * [[2010 Copiapó mining accident]], a similarly highly covered event * [[Kathy Fiscus]], a child who died after falling into a well in 1949 * [[Alfredo Rampi]], a child who died after falling into a well in 1981 * [[Tikki Tikki Tembo]] * ''[[The Well (1951 film)|The Well]]'', 1951 film in which a little girl falls into a well and the town unites to save her by drilling a parallel shaft == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|id=1532391|name=Jessica McClure}} *"[http://www.vqronline.org/articles/1988/summer/brockbroido-jessica-from-well/ Jessica, from the Well]" poem by Lucie Brock-Broido {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McClure, Jessica}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:1987 in Texas]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:People from Midland, Texas]]
