{{Infobox animal | name = Toughie | image = Ecnomiohyla rabborum.jpg | caption = | species = ''[[Ecnomiohyla rabborum]]'' | gender = Male | hatch_date = Unknown. Captured in 2005. | hatch_place = | death_date = September 26, 2016 | death_place = [[Atlanta Botanical Garden]]<ref name="Rare frog goes extinct, despite Atlanta’s rescue efforts">{{cite news |author=Bo Emerson |title=Rare frog goes extinct, despite Atlanta’s rescue efforts |url=http://www.accessatlanta.com/news/news/rare-frog-goes-extinct-despite-atlantas-rescue-eff/nsgkt/ |newspaper=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date=28 September 2016 |access-date=28 September 2016}}</ref>
| resting_place = | known = [[Endling|Last known living]] Rabbs' fringe-limbed treefrog }} '''Toughie''' was the [[Endling|last known living]] [[Rabbs' fringe-limbed treefrog]]. The species, scientifically known as ''Ecnomiohyla rabborum'', is thought to be [[Extinction|extinct]], as the last specimen—Toughie—died in captivity on September 26, 2016.<ref name="Rare frog goes extinct, despite Atlanta’s rescue efforts">{{cite news |author=Bo Emerson |title=Rare frog goes extinct, despite Atlanta’s rescue efforts |url=http://www.accessatlanta.com/news/news/rare-frog-goes-extinct-despite-atlantas-rescue-eff/nsgkt/ |newspaper=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date=28 September 2016 |access-date=28 September 2016}}</ref>
==Captivity== Toughie was captured as an adult in [[Panama]] in 2005, when researchers went on a conservation mission to rescue species from ''[[Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis]]'', a fungus deadly to amphibians. Toughie was one of "several dozen" frogs and tadpoles of the same species to be transported back to the United States.<ref name=natgeopub1>{{cite news|title=Rabb's Fringe-limbed Treefrog featured in this month's National Geographic!|url=http://frogpodblog.blogspot.com/2013/06/rabbs-fringe-limbed-treefrog-featured.html|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=Atlanta Botanical Garden|date=17 Jun 2013}}</ref>
Toughie lived at the [[Atlanta Botanical Garden]] in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. At the Garden, he was placed in a special containment area called the "frogPOD", a biosecure enclosure. Visitors to the Garden are not allowed to visit the frogPOD, as it is used to house critically endangered animals.<ref name=ABG1>{{cite news|title=Rabb's Fringe-limbed tree frog update|url=http://atlantabg.org/learn/conservation-efforts/amphibian-conservation|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=Atlanta Botanical Garden|date=16 October 2014}}</ref> While in captivity at the Garden, Toughie sired tadpoles with a female, but none survived. After the female died, the only other known specimen in the world was a male, leaving Toughie no other options of reproducing.<ref name=usatoday1 /> The other male, who lived at the [[Zoo Atlanta]], was euthanized on February 17, 2012, due to health concerns.<ref name=zooatlanta1>{{cite news|title=It’s Leap Year. Remember the Rabbs’ tree frog.|url=http://www.zooatlanta.org/home/article_content/leapyear#nuRFs|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=Zoo Atlanta|date=17 Feb 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524060207/http://www.zooatlanta.org/home/article_content/leapyear#nuRFs|archivedate=24 May 2012|df=}}</ref>
Since Toughie was brought in as an adult to the Garden, they do not know his age but estimated that he was about 12 years old.<ref name=Hullinger1>{{cite news|last1=Hullinger|first1=Jeff|title=Last-of-its-kind tree frog at Atlanta Botanical Gardens|url=http://archive.11alive.com/news/article/299835/1/Last-of-its-kind-tree-frog-lives-at-Atlanta-Botanical-Gardens|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=Atlanta 11|date=23 July 2013}}</ref> On December 15, 2014, Toughie was recorded vocalizing again. It is his first known call since being collected as an adult in 2005.<ref name="call">{{cite web|url=http://frogpodblog.blogspot.com/2014/12/the-rabbs-fringe-limbed-tree-frog.html|title=The Rabbs' Fringe-Limbed Tree Frog called again ... after years ... and we recorded it! |author=frogPOD|date=17 December 2014|publisher=Atlanta Botanical Garden|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref>
Toughie died on September 26, 2016 at the Garden.<ref name="Rare frog goes extinct, despite Atlanta’s rescue efforts">{{cite news |author=Bo Emerson |title=Rare frog goes extinct, despite Atlanta’s rescue efforts |url=http://www.accessatlanta.com/news/news/rare-frog-goes-extinct-despite-atlantas-rescue-eff/nsgkt/ |newspaper=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date=28 September 2016 |access-date=28 September 2016}}</ref>
==Personal characteristics== Toughie was given his name by Mark Mandica's son Anthony. <ref name=HuffingtonPost>{{cite news|title=The Loneliest Frog in the World|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/leilani-munter/the-loneliest-frog-in-the_b_5940426.html|accessdate=28 September 2016|publisher=Huffington Post|date=7 Dec 2014}}</ref> Mark Mandica was Toughie's caretaker for many years at the Atlanta Botanical Garden. Toughie did not like to be handled. He would pinch a handler's hand in an attempt to "say 'let me go'", according to handler Leslie Phillips.<ref name=usatoday1>{{cite news|title='Toughie' is last of his species of tree frog|url=https://www.usatoday.com/media/cinematic/video/2580713/toughie-is-last-of-his-species-of-tree-frog/|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=USA Today|date=23 July 2013}}</ref> She continued with, "For me it is incredibly motivating working with the Rabbs' frog. Having him here is a constant reminder of what can potentially happen to other species if we don't continue the conservation work that we do here at the Atlanta Botanical Garden. Honestly, it is also nerve-racking at times working with him. It can be a challenging balance between leaving him alone as much as possible to avoid undue stress, while still providing the best possible care... He is just really cool. No other frog I have seen is quite like him. He is muscular and has giant webbed feet and big eyes ... He is a very handsome frog."<ref name=mother1>{{cite news|last1=Norris|first1=Anna|title=Taking care of Toughie, the last of his kind|url=http://www.mnn.com/earth-matters/animals/stories/taking-care-of-toughie-the-last-of-his-kind|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=Mother Nature Network}}</ref> Handlers tried to touch him as little as possible, but they did weigh him once a week to keep track of his health.<ref name=Moreira1>{{cite news|last1=Moreira|first1=Naila|title=The loss of the frog prince|url=http://www.nailamoreira.com/the-loss-of-the-frog-prince/|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=NailaMoreira.com|date=26 September 2013}}</ref>
==Featured in projects== In July 2013, ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' featured Toughie and his species in their magazine. It is part of the 'Photo Ark' project run by photographer [[Joel Sartore]]. They also focused on the Atlanta Botanical Garden's Amphibian Conservation Program.<ref name=ABGagain>{{cite news|title=Atlanta Botanical Garden frogPOD|url=http://atlantabotanicalgarden.org/conservation/atlanta-botanical-garden-frogpod|accessdate=5 October 2014|publisher=Atlanta Botanical Garden}}</ref>
In 2014, [[Louie Psihoyos]] filmed Toughie for his 2015 film ''Racing Extinction'', including footage of Sartore photographing him. To promote the film and the extinction crisis, a 30-story series of photographs was projected onto the side of the [[United Nations Building]] in [[New York City]] in September 2014. Included was a photograph of Toughie.<ref name=UNbldg1>{{cite news|title=Our Rabbs' Fringed Limbed Tree Frog and other species projected on the UN Building last weekend!|url=http://frogpodblog.blogspot.com/2014/09/our-rabbs-fringed-limbed-tree-frog-and.html|accessdate=5 October 2014|issue=24 Sep 2014|publisher=Atlanta Botanical Garden}}</ref>

{{About|the [[Torah]] binder|the woman's headgear|wimple}} [[Image:Wimpel pixelated.jpg|thumb|center|600px|A modern Wimpel with the name obscured]] {{Judaism}} A '''wimpel''' ({{lang-yi|ווימפל}}, from [[German language|German]], "cloth," derived from Old German, ''bewimfen,'' meaning "to cover up" or "conceal")Kaniel, Dr. Michael. "The Wimpel: Binding the Family to the Torah". ''[[Jewish Action]]'', Summer 1993, Vol. 53, No. 3, pp. 41-44. is a long, [[linen]] sash used as a binding for the [[Sefer Torah]] by [[Jew]]s of [[Ashkenazi Jews|Germanic]] ([[Yekke]]) origin. It is made from the cloth used to swaddle a baby boy at his [[bris milah]], uniting the communal world of the [[synagogue]] with the individual's own life cycle.{{cite web|url=http://www.skirball.org/press/archives/wedding.html |title=Romance & Ritual: Celebrating the Jewish Wedding |accessdate= 2007-07-06}} The wimpel is an offshoot of a common Jewish practice. In the times of the [[Tannaim]], all Torah scrolls were wrapped only with a cloth, known in Hebrew as a “mappah,” or in German, a “wimpel.” As with other holy Judaic objects, donating a mappah was considered to be a great [[mitzvah]] and honor, and very often a groom would donate one on the eve of his wedding. Most of these were made from old clothing. While some Rabbis approved of this practice, others did not because they felt that it was not proper respect for the Torah. Unlike these controversial “second-hand” mappot, the cloth used at a baby’s circumcision was undoubtedly holy, and it gradually became the custom to donate these as mappot. There are many variations as to what takes place at the actual wimpel ceremony. One common approach is to bring it to synagogue when the boy turns three and is toilet-trained. He and his father get the [[Aliyah (Torah)|aliyah]] of [[Gelila#Hagbaha|gelilah]], and together they wrap the wimpel around the Torah. (Variations include the child's age, the type of aliyah, and the extent of the child's participation in the actual ceremony.) Afterwards, the family invites the community to join them for a [[Kiddush#Kiddush reception|kiddush]], a small celebratory party. This custom is still observed today by most members of the German community. It is an extremely joyous occasion, and its main purpose is to instill a love and enthusiasm for [[shul]] and Judaism within the child. ==Origins== Some attribute the origins of the custom to a story recorded about a time when the [[wikt:Maharil|Maharil]] was the [[sandek]]. It is customary to wrap a baby’s legs after the circumcision to prevent him from moving around and knocking the bandages out of place. On this particular occasion, the circumciser, known as the "[[mohel]]", suddenly realized that he had forgotten to bring along the cloth for the baby's legs. The Maharil felt that this was a life-threatening situation, and he instructed the mohel to use a spare mappah from one of the synagogue’s Torahs as the cloth. The Maharil also told the child's parents to wash it once they were done with it and return it to the synagogue with a minor contribution. However, there are reasons to believe that the practice of using the cloth from the circumcision predates the Maharil, and the story is only of interest to illustrate that the cloth, even after being sanctified with the holiness of the Sefer Torah, may be used for the wrapping of the baby at the circumcision. See Rabbi Rabbi [[Binyamin Shlomo Hamburger]]'s Shoroshei Minhag Ashkenaz for more details about this discussion. [[Image:Wimpel in Worms.jpg|thumb|left|On display in the Jewish Museum in [[Worms, Germany]]: Wimpels which were damaged during [[Kristallnacht]]]] This incident highlighted the connection between the Torah and circumcision, as both relate to covenants that the Jewish people have with God (the covenants of Torah and circumcision). The custom gradually developed into the one that is practiced today by German Jews: At a baby's circumcision, the mohel places a long swatch of white cloth - the wimpel – under the pillow. Afterwards, the wimpel is beautifully decorated – it can be either painted or embroidered – with the child’s name, date of birth, and the Hebrew phrase which states “Just like he entered the [covenant of] circumcision, so too he should [the covenant of] Torah, marriage, and good deeds.” Some mothers do the artwork themselves; others retain the services of “wimpel professionals,” e.g., men or women who do this as a side job or hobby. Another explanation comes from an 80-year-old lady who remembers a ceremony from her synagogue in Germany, where the young child was brought to the synagogue once he was free of diapers, and the women would throw the Wimpel on the torah, while the men carried the torah below ezrat nashim. The Wimpel was then dedicated to the synagogue, symbolizing the fact the child is now pure, and can take part in the service. ==Creating the wimpel== The wimpel is created shortly after the brit milah using the swaddling cloth that was used at that ceremony. The cloth is cleaned, cut into strips and sewn into a sash measuring six or seven inches wide and ten or twelve feet long. The child’s Hebrew name and date of birth are painted or embroidered onto the cloth, usually by the mother or grandmother,{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/haventohome/haven-century.html |title=A Century of Immigration, 1820-1924 |accessdate= 2007-07-06}} along with the traditional [[List of Jewish prayers and blessings|blessing]]: * ה' יגדלהו לתורה ולחופה ולמעשים טובים אמן *"...may God raise him up to [a life of] Torah, a [[Jewish view of marriage|successful marriage]], and [[Mitzvah|good deeds]], [[Amen]]." Colorful images such as animals, birds and [[astrological sign]]s, and scenes pertaining to the blessing – such as a bride and groom under the [[chuppah]] and a Sefer Torah – have also adorned modern and old-world wimpels. ==Bringing the wimpel== [[File:WLA jewishmuseum Torah Binder.jpg|thumb|left|Wimpel painted on linen, [[Jewish Museum (New York)]]]] When the child comes of age to begin learning Torah (age 3), he and his family bring the wimpel to the [[synagogue]] for [[Shabbat]] morning services. After the Torah reading, the child performs the ritual of [[gelila]], perhaps with the help of his father, by wrapping the wimpel many times around the Torah scroll and tucking the end of the cloth into the folds. In this way, the child’s individual responsibilities to God and His commandments are literally wrapped around his communal responsibilities, a figurative lesson for the child and his family. Rabbi [[Shimon Schwab]], Rav of [[Khal Adath Yeshurun]] synagogue in [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]], [[New York (state)|New York]], which revived the custom among the younger generation of Yekke congregants, suggested that perhaps the source of the wimpel custom was to avoid knotting and unknotting a tie around the Torah on Shabbat (''see'' [[Shabbat#Orthodox Judaism and the 39 categories of activity|the 39 categories of activity prohibited on the Sabbath]]). On that first [[Shabbat]] that the wimpel is presented and used, the child's family makes a [[Kiddush#Kiddush reception|kiddush]] in honor of their son's entering into a life of Torah. ==Other uses== The synagogue typically receives many more wimpels than Torah scrolls. The wimpels are often stored in a drawer in the [[Ark (synagogue)|Ark]]. A boy's wimpel would then be placed on the Torah on other special occasions in his life, such as his [[B'nai Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]], [[Aufruf]], and other important family events. Some wimpels were even used as a decorative banner on the chuppah itself. ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.thejewishmuseum.org/site/pages/zCollection_details.php?num=243&type=zoom Das Schultragen] The Presentation at the Synagogue, 1869 By [[Moritz Daniel Oppenheim]] *[http://www.beth-tzedec.org/PhotoGallery-section-4573-46/;jsessionid=07EE693BFB48A11DF57F7BD26C224B62?jt_style=section&jt_section=12&eid=46&skip=0&len=1000 Photo of wimpel made in Germany in 1694] *[http://www.wimpel.org/ wimpel.org] Information and instructions for modern-day wimpel-making

{{Infobox military person |name = Şerife Bacı |birth_date = c. 1900 |death_date = December 1921 |death_place = [[Kastamonu]] |placeofburial = |placeofburial_label = |image = Inebolu2007 0101 135130a.JPG |image_size = 200px |caption = Statue of Şerife Bacı by [[Metin Yurdanur]] in the coastal park of İnebolu. |nickname = |allegiance = {{flag|Ottoman Empire}}
{{flag|Turkey}} |branch = |serviceyears = |rank = |commands = |unit= |battles = |awards = |laterwork = }} '''Şerife Bacı''' (literally: Sister Şerife), aka '''Şerife Kadın''' for "Mrs. Şerife", (born c. 1900 – died December 1921) was a [[Turkey|Turkish]] [[folk hero]]ine, who took part in the [[Turkish War of Independence]], and was declared a [[martyr]] due to her death during the war. ==Early life== She was born in a village in the [[Seydiler]] district of [[Kastamonu Vilayet]]. Her birth date is not known for certain. However, she was sixteen years old when she got married. Two months after her wedding, [[World War I]] broke out, and her husband was recruited. Six months later, she learnt of the death of her husband in the [[Gallipoli Campaign]] (1915–16). The villagers arranged her re-marriage to a wounded war veteran named Topal Yusuf (literally: Yusuf the Lame), who had lost his left leg and an eye in a bomb explosion at the front. In the third year of her re-marriage, Şerife Gelin (literally: Bride Şerife) as she was called, gave birth to a daughter named Elif. Şerife was a helpful person for almost everyone and every work in the village.{{cite web |url=http://www.serifebaci.org/arsiv/3-flash-haberler/3-sehit-serife-bacinin-hikayesi.html |publisher=Şerife Bacı |title=Şerife Bacı'nın Hikayesi |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }}{{cite news |url=http://blog.radikal.com.tr/Sayfa/kurtulus-savasinda-bir-kadin-kahraman-serife-baci-28142 |newspaper=[[Radikal]] |title=Kurtuluş savaşında bir kadın kahraman: Şerife Bacı |date=2013-07-21 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }} ==Death== In the winter of 1921, the villagers were called to help transport ammunition needed in the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919–22)|Greco-Turkish War]]. She was on a trek together with her child and some other women carrying cannonballs on her oxen-driven [[tumbrel]] from [[İnebolu]] to [[Ankara]]. She was found dead shortly before the Kastamonu Barracks, perished from cold due to severe winter conditions in December 1921.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/19932697.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=40 kadın Şerife Bacı için yürüyecek |date=2012-02-16 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.kenthaber.com/karadeniz/kastamonu/merkez/Rehber/anit-ve-heykeller/ataturk-ve-sehit-serife-baci-aniti |newspaper=Kent Haber |title=Atatürk ve Şehit Şerife Bacı Anıtı |date=2008-03-02 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }} ==Recognition== In memorial of the 50th anniversary of the foundation of the Republic, the district mayor of Seydiler built 1973 a relief in her honor. In 1990, a monument by [[Tankut Öktem]] depicting [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk|Atatürk]], Şerife Bacı and the women of Kastamonu in the War of Independence was placed in the Republic Square of the city. A monument in honor of "Martyr Şerife Bacı" was erected in the public park on the coast of İnebolu, commissioned by the [[List of General Commanders of the Gendarmerie of Turkey|General Commander of the Gendarmerie]] [[Aytaç Yalman]] and created by sculptor [[Metin Yurdanur]]. Its inauguration took place on December 4, 2001. Martyr Şerife Bacı is a symbol of the heroic Turkish women in the War of Independence. Many institutions such as schools and hospitals are named after her in Kastamonu{{cite web |url=http://sehitserifebaci.meb.k12.tr/ |publisher=MEB Kastamonu Şehit Şerife Bacı Otaokulu |title=Okulumuzun Sene Sonu Şenliği |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }} and other cities{{cite web |url=http://mebk12.meb.gov.tr/meb_iys_dosyalar/34/26/973090/okulumuz_hakkinda.html |publisher=MEB İstanbul Büyükşehir Şehit Şerife Bacı Kız Teknik ve Meslek Lisesi |title=Okulumuz Hakkında |language=Turkish|accessdate=2013-09-29 }}{{cite web |url=http://mebk12.meb.gov.tr/meb_iys_dosyalar/41/11/974502/ |publisher=MEB Dilovası Şerife Bacı Anaokulu |title=Okulumuzda "Kostümler Yarışıyor" |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }}{{cite web |url=http://mebk12.meb.gov.tr/meb_iys_dosyalar/35/07/974598/ |publisher=MEB İzmir Buca Şerife Bacı Kız Teknik ve Meslek Lisesi |title=Tarihçe |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }} in Turkey. In February 2012, twelve of the initially planned forty women from Kastamonu hiked the distance of {{convert|105|km|mi|abbr=on}} from İnebolu to Kastamonu in three days under winter conditions to commemorate Şerife Bacı's deadly trek 91 years ago.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/19951743.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Kadınlar Şerife Bacı için 105 km yürüyecek |author=Yıldırım, Fethican |date=2012-02-19 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-08-29 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{commons category|Martyr Şerife Bacı Monument}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baci, Serife}} [[Category:1890s births]] [[Category:1921 deaths]] [[Category:People from Seydiler]] [[Category:People from Kastamonu Vilayet]] [[Category:Women of the Ottoman Empire in warfare]] [[Category:National Heroes of Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish people of the Turkish War of Independence]] [[Category:Turkish revolutionaries]] [[Category:Women in the Turkish War of Independence]] [[Category:Deaths from hypothermia]]
